Knowledge Point: The two most versatile basic forms, proximal wa and distal me, typically evoke participant-anchored spatial information. An illustration of each is given in~(\ref{exe:kewewa}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The far distal is typically used on a bigger scale, across landscape. An example is~(\ref{exe:yonder}). The far distal basic form owa is hardly found uninflected. In this example, it carries a demonstrative suffix -ne, which I comment upon below.
Content 1: \gll lempuang temun=a \textbf{owa}-ne tumun-un=a wa | \gls island big=FOC FDIST-DEM child-3POSS=FOC PROX | \glt `The big island is yonder, the small one is here.'

Knowledge Point: The elevational demonstratives refer to referents on a vertical axis: osa and yawe are used for referents which are located higher and lower, respectively, than the speaker or another point of reference. (\ref{exe:adisor}) and~(\ref{exe:yawee}) are adnominal uses.
Content 1: \gll adi sor \textbf{osa} [...] kabaruap | \gls DER fish UP {\ob}...{\cb} grouper | \glt `That fish up there {\ob}...{\cb} is a grouper.'
Content 2: \gll ma tamatko ka bo minggalot-an \textbf{yawe} kome=te | \gls 3SG where 2SG go bedroom-1SG.POSS DOWN look=IMP | \glt `Where is it? You go look in my bedroom down there!'

Knowledge Point: The anaphoric demonstrative opa occurs with referents that in some respect represent knowledge already shared by the speaker and the addressee, typically those that are previously mentioned in discourse. The latter is the case with the referent dodon `clothing' in~(\ref{exe:dodonop}).
Content 1: \gll dodon \textbf{opa} an masa | \gls clothing ANA 1SG dry_in_sun | \glt `I dried those clothes [that we talked about] in the sun.'

Knowledge Point: As an introduction, consider the following example. The two most versatile basic forms, the proximal wa and the distal me, typically evoke speaker-oriented spatial information. This is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kewewaa}), repeated from §\ref{sec:basicdem}, where speaker A uses the proximal form for a picture that is on the table in front of him. Speaker B first uses the distal form, and then switches to the proximal form in combination with pointing, because speaker A has now picked up the picture so that B is closer to it.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: These basic forms, as well as the far distal owa, have additional semantic and pragmatic properties other than the spatial ones. In the following sections, temporal, manner, anaphoric and other uses of the demonstratives are described. With such a plethora of forms and functions, it is not surprising that we find utterances like~(\ref{exe:pai}). Taken from an explanation about the use of plant medicine, it shows a nice combination of the pragmatic use of demonstratives (metko as a sequential marker and the expression ma he me, discussed in §\ref{sec:discdems}) and the spatial semantics of demonstratives (predicative watko `here' and pronominal wane `this').
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Figure~\ref{fig:wane} shows the video stills from the time of utterance of the three spatial demonstratives in~(\ref{exe:pai}), which are accompanied by pointing.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Proximal demonstrative wa is prototypically used adnominally, pronominally and identificationally to indicate referents that are close to the speaker. (\ref{exe:waratu}) illustrates an adnominal and~(\ref{exe:dempro}) a pronominal use of the proximal demonstrative, both in object position (hence the object form wat). The demonstrative in~(\ref{exe:waratu}) refers to a woman in a picture in front of the speaker, with the speaker pointing at her. The demonstrative in~(\ref{exe:dempro}) stands in for a fishing net the speaker is holding.
Content 1: \gll ma enem \textbf{wat}=a tu | \gls 3SG woman PROX.OBJ=FOC hit | \glt `He hits this woman.'
Content 2: \gll ki \textbf{wat} napaki=kin ye ge | \gls 2PL PROX.OBJ use=VOL or not | \glt `Are you going to use this or not?'
Content 3: \gll ma enem \textbf{wat}=a tu | \gls 3SG woman PROX.OBJ=FOC hit | \glt `He hits this woman.'
Content 4: \gll ki \textbf{wat} napaki=kin ye ge | \gls 2PL PROX.OBJ use=VOL or not | \glt `Are you going to use this or not?'

Knowledge Point: Two identificational examples are given in~(\ref{exe:namunawa}) and~(\ref{exe:dauanawa}). In~(\ref{exe:namunawa}), the speaker points at a picture with three people and identifies them one by one. (\ref{exe:dauanawa}) is from a story about a wedding, where the names of the bride's and groom's families are called out as a way of introducing the family members to couple. Note that an identificational demonstrative follows a \is{focus}focused noun, but precedes a \is{topic}topicalised noun.
Content 1: \gll namun=a \textbf{wa} kiun=a \textbf{wa} tumun-un=a \textbf{wa} | \gls husband.3POSS=FOC PROX wife-3POSS=FOC PROX child-3POSS=FOC PROX | \glt `This is the husband, this is the wife, this is their child.'
Content 2: \gll supaya canam gonggin ma toni o \textbf{wa} me dauk-an=a \textbf{wa} ketan-an=a \textbf{wa} esa-an=a \textbf{wa} mama-an=a \textbf{wa} | \gls so_that man know 3SG say INT PROX TOP sibling_in_law-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX parent_in_law-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX uncle-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX uncle-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX | \glt `So that the man knows, he says: ``O, this is my sibling-in-law, this is my parent-in-law, this is my uncle, this is my uncle.'''
Content 3: \gll namun=a \textbf{wa} kiun=a \textbf{wa} tumun-un=a \textbf{wa} | \gls husband.3POSS=FOC PROX wife-3POSS=FOC PROX child-3POSS=FOC PROX | \glt `This is the husband, this is the wife, this is their child.'
Content 4: \gll supaya canam gonggin ma toni o \textbf{wa} me dauk-an=a \textbf{wa} ketan-an=a \textbf{wa} esa-an=a \textbf{wa} mama-an=a \textbf{wa} | \gls so_that man know 3SG say INT PROX TOP sibling_in_law-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX parent_in_law-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX uncle-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX uncle-1SG.POSS=FOC PROX | \glt `So that the man knows, he says: ``O, this is my sibling-in-law, this is my parent-in-law, this is my uncle, this is my uncle.'''

Knowledge Point: The longer forms wane and yuwane are often used identificationally, typically when identifying the right-hand picture in a picture-matching task\is{picture-matching task} (example~\ref{exe:mawane}). They may also be pronominal (example~\ref{exe:wanet}) or adnominal (example~\ref{exe:konyuwane}).
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{wane} | \gls 3SG PROX | \glt `This is it.'
Content 2: \gll mu toni ya \textbf{wanet} me rasa | \gls 3PL say yes PROX.OBJ TOP like | \glt `They said: ``Yes, this is good.'''
Content 3: \gll neba kon=a yuwa sor tumun kon \textbf{yuwane} sor sair=ten | \gls what one=FOC PROX fish small one PROX fish bake=AT | \glt `What is this one here, this one small fish here, baking fish?'

Knowledge Point: The locative and lative proximal forms watko `here' and wangga `to/from here' are used for indicating the \is{location}location of referents close to the speaker. In~(\ref{exe:ramin}), the speaker uses watko to refer to her side of the fishing net, while the addressee is holding the other side a few metres away. In~(\ref{exe:hadiwat}), proximal watko refers to Mas village, which is where the speaker is when she utters the sentence.
Content 1: \gll ka-mun mindi rami=in mena ma \textbf{watko} | \gls 2SG-PROH like_that pull=PROH otherwise 3SG PROX.LOC | \glt `Don't you pull like that, otherwise it will be here.'
Content 2: \gll Hadi me \textbf{watko} | \gls Hadi TOP PROX.LOC | \glt `Hadi was here.'

Knowledge Point: Watko can be used in combination with pointing. (\ref{exe:komana}) is uttered while the speaker points at the eye of a fish lure.
Content 1: \gll an kona \textbf{watko}=a komain=et kanggir-un=ko to | \gls 1SG think PROX.LOC=FOC puncture=IRR eye-3POSS=LOC right | \glt `I think you puncture it here, in its eye, right?'

Knowledge Point: %There are two instances of the proximal demonstrative post-predicately, which function I do not quite understand. They could have some kind of emphasising function. Alternatively, yuwa in example~\ref{exe:rekamda} is temporal use (`she is recording is at this very moment') and yuwa in example~\ref{exe:karayuwa} is spatial (`here are the fish I'm presenting you with').
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The proximal demonstrative wandi expresses manner or quality, and usually modifies a verb. The verb can be left out when the speaker enacts the action they are referring to. The speaker in~(\ref{exe:wandirami}) explains to the addressee how to pull bait. First, she uses wandi `like this' without a verb, while enacting the movement and encouraging the addressee to look at her, and then repeats wandi followed by the verb rami `to pull'. Proximal wandi is typically used when the speaker is simultaneously imitating a movement or a situation with gestures.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Proximal wandi can also be used to refer to states, such as `being friends' in (\ref{exe:friends}) or a colour (in~\ref{exe:black}, the speaker points at the black microphone stand). Both examples use the long form yuwandi.
Content 1: \gll taman-un kodaet me ka=bon an=bon \textbf{yuwandi} | \gls friend-3POSS one_more TOP 2SG=COM 1SG=COM like_this | \glt `He has a friend like you and me.'
Content 2: \gll se bo kuskap=ten \textbf{yuwandi} | \gls IAM go black=TEN like_this | \glt `[The nutmegs] turn black like this.'

Knowledge Point: Lastly, proximal wandi can be used to introduce quoted speech (as in \ref{exe:kadokca}, see also §\ref{sec:speech}) or as a stand-in for quoted speech, as in (\ref{exe:wandiwandi}).
Content 1: \gll an se \textbf{wandi} eh ema kadok-ca=at=a tama | \gls 1SG IAM like_this INT aunt cloth-2SG.POSS=OBJ=FOC where | \glt `I went like: ``Hey aunt, where is your cloth?'''
Content 2: \gll ma toni \textbf{wandi} \textbf{wandi} | \gls 3SG say like_this like_this | \glt `He said such-and-such.'

Knowledge Point: Distal demonstrative me occurs adnominally, pronominally and identificationally, prototypically to indicate referents that are relatively far from the speaker. There are no adnominal examples in the naturalistic corpus that are clearly spatial, so an elicited example is given in~(\ref{exe:demadme}). It was elicited for a situation where the speaker points at one of the addressee's teeth (scene 2 from \citealt{wilkins1999}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In object position, the distal demonstrative has the form met, as is illustrated for pronominal use in~(\ref{exe:demprome}). The distal demonstrative refers to betel nuts, which the referent of ma `she' went to look for in another house.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Identificational examples are given in~(\ref{exe:demidme}) and~(\ref{exe:demidmeme}). Like for proximal forms, the distal demonstrative follows a \is{focus}focused noun and precedes a \is{topic}topic marker.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Distal metko `there' is used for indicating the \is{location}location of referents away from the speaker. In~(\ref{exe:maulma}), the distal location is first specified (the sea) and then referred to with metko. (\ref{exe:kasawari}) is from a story about a dog and a cassowary which chased each other into the sea and became rock formations.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Metko, like other NPs carrying a locative postposition, can be used predicatively, essentially meaning `to be there'. Mengga, like other NPs carrying the lative postposition, must always be used in combination with other verbs. An example is given in~(\ref{exe:mengga1}). Complex source, goal and location constructions are described in §\ref{sec:mvcgoal}.
Content 1: \gll terus \textbf{mengga} koi Ibrahim tanbes=ko \textbf{mengga} koi Arepnengga bara | \gls further DIST.LAT then Ibrahim right=LOC from_there then Arepner.LAT descend | \glt `Further from there there's Ibrahim on the right, from there down to Arepner.'

Knowledge Point: Temporal use of demonstratives is largely restricted to the distal form modifying the noun yuol `day', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:yuolmeme}) and~(\ref{exe:yuolme}).
Content 1: \gll yuol \textbf{me} me ma masin=at istar | \gls day DIST TOP 3SG machine=OBJ start | \glt `That day he started the machine.'
Content 2: \gll ma se mu=bon taruon ma kasian yuol \textbf{me} ma se taruo | \gls 3SG IAM 3PL=COM say 3SG poor day DIST 3SG IAM say | \glt `She already told them, poor her, that day she already told.'

Knowledge Point: Clear endophoric usage of the distal demonstrative as in~(\ref{exe:canamme}), where me refers back to a referent introduced earlier (anaphora), is rather rare.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The distal form mindi `like that' (occasionally pronounced mendi, cf. the distal basic form me) expresses manner or quality. In~(\ref{exe:mindijaga}), the speaker tries to explain how they waved away the smoke of fires with leaves to keep their hiding place secret during the Japanese bombings in WWII.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Distal mindi is also used as `until' in combination with bo `to go' (lit. `go like that', see also §\ref{sec:svcmanneri}). (\ref{exe:karuar}) is about the production of pandanus leaf strips for weaving.
Content 1: \gll karuar=i \textbf{mindi} bo kararak koi masan | \gls smoke_dry=PLNK like_that go dry then dry_in_sun | \glt `We dry [on a rack above the fire] until it's dry, then we dry in the sun.'

Knowledge Point: The form mendak `just like that', which seems derived from distal me and =tak `just', is also used to express manner. Consider~(\ref{exe:mendak}). There is no corresponding proximal form (see also §\ref{sec:mvcuntil}).
Content 1: \gll pi \textbf{mendak} kuar langsung=et eba bes | \gls 1PL.EXCL just_like_that cook directly=IRR then good | \glt `If we just cook it directly like that, it's good.'

Knowledge Point: Distal manner demonstrative mindi is used to indicate a new scene in a story. (\ref{exe:mindimu}) is uttered after an intermezzo in Papuan Malay. The story is taken up again starting with mindi. In (\ref{exe:matyie}), mindi marks the transition between two scenes: that of the speaker going off for a swim, and that of his friend calling him. Mindi also indicates that some time has passed between the speaker going off for a swim, and his friend calling him.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The expression ma he me `that's it', containing distal me, is used to indicate the end of a paragraph, usually one that has a summary of different things or actions, such as the list of ingredients in~(\ref{exe:gelompang}). It can also close off an entire story, in combination with se koyet `finished' (as in~\ref{exe:theend}, see also §\ref{sec:closing}).
Content 1: \gll gelompang eba wat santang=bon terus kokok-nar eba nasuena \textbf{ma} \textbf{se} \textbf{me} | \gls batter then coconut coconut_milk=COM then chicken-egg then sugar 3SG IAM DIST | \glt `The batter. With coconut milk, eggs, sugar, that's it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{ma} \textbf{se} \textbf{me} se koyet | \gls 3SG IAM DIST IAM finish | \glt `That's it, finished.'

Knowledge Point: Ma he me can also mean `that's enough', as in~(\ref{exe:eih}), where a monkey wants to be released from his cage.
Content 1: \gll eih \textbf{ma} \textbf{se} \textbf{me} \textbf{ma} \textbf{se} \textbf{me} an=at kahetmei | \gls hey 3SG IAM DIST 3SG IAM DIST 1SG=OBJ open.IMP | \glt `Hey, that's enough, that's enough, release me!'

Knowledge Point: Finally mera, possibly derived from distal demonstrative or topic marker me and non-final =ta (homonymous with the focused object form of the distal demonstrative), is used as a conjunction for either sequential events as in~(\ref{exe:davite}) or for reason and consequence as in~(\ref{exe:merame}).
Content 1: \gsrc  Ma lalaren. \textbf{Mera} ma he ecua. | \gls ma lalat=ten mera ma se ecua | \gls 3SG dead={\glten} so 3SG {\glse} cry\\

Knowledge Point: Far distal owa is prototypically used for referents that are relatively very far away from the speaker and the listener. It is mostly used when referring to places across landscape, e.g. the next beach, behind the mountain, another city, the other side of the island, the other side of the country. This results in owa typically, but not necessarily, being used for invisible referents. In the recordings from a round trip around the biggest Karas island, speakers tend to use owa for singling out landscape features that are not only somewhat distant, but also have another landscape feature in between. In~(\ref{exe:owane}), the speaker points at Yar Poskon, a cape 100 metres away, while sailing past another cape which is followed by a beach and Yar Poskon.
Content 1: \gll Yar Poskon=a owane | \gls Yar Poskon=FOC FDIST | \glt `Yar Poskon is over there!'

Knowledge Point: In about half of the corpus instances (23 out of 47), owa carries a lative or locative postposition. This is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:ruomun}) to~(\ref{exe:belada}). The principles are the same: owatko and owangga are used to refer across landscape. The referent may be close, as in~(\ref{exe:kol}), where the location referred to is right outside the house, or in another country, as in~(\ref{exe:belada}).
Content 1: \gll ra Pebis Ruomun \textbf{owangga} in=at nawaruok | \gls go Pebis Ruomun FDIST.LAT 1PL.EXCL=OBJ unload | \glt `[You want to] go to Pebis Ruomun over there and drop us off?'
Content 2: \gll Beladar-leng \textbf{owatko} | \gls Netherlands-village over_there | \glt `In the Dutch village over there.'
Content 3: \gll bo kol \textbf{owatko} war=te | \gls go outside over_there fish=IMP | \glt `Go fish outside over there!'
Content 4: \gll Beladar-leng \textbf{owatko} | \gls Netherlands-village over_there | \glt `In the Dutch village over there.'

Knowledge Point: One corpus example of owa (in its variant owane) is used on a much smaller scale: a table top in a picture-matching task\is{picture-matching task}. During this task, the director could see the matcher's pictures, and directed him to the correct picture by explaining the position of the card with the picture on the tabletop. The director utters~(\ref{exe:elakdok}). Owane is used to indicate that the picture is at the far extreme of the tabletop, far away from the speaker (and the addressee) as compared to the other pictures.
Content 1: \gll elak-kadok tua elak-kadok siun-kadok \textbf{owane} | \gls bottom-side old_man bottom-side edge-side FDIST | \glt `Down there, Tua, down there, at the edge over there.'

Knowledge Point: Far distal locative owatko `over there', while usually used for invisible \is{location}locations, can also be used when the location is far away from both the speaker and the addressee, and when the speaker wants to create a mental distance to the referent. (\ref{exe:owatkin}) comes from a conversation between two sisters who are fishing with their much younger sister-in-law. They are not satisfied with her skills, and tease her. In the utterance, the speaker and the addressee stand next to each other in the sea, and refer to the sister-in-law who is standing fifty metres away, but is clearly visible.
Content 1: \gll mena ma se koi \textbf{owatko} kinkin=taet reon | \gls otherwise 3SG IAM again over_there hold=again maybe | \glt `Otherwise she will maybe hold [the fishing net] again over there.'

Knowledge Point: Opa is an adnominal demonstrative. It occurs with referents that represent shared knowledge, typically because they have been previously mentioned in the \is{discourse}discourse. It has mainly tracking and recognitional uses \parencite{himmelmann1996}, and is therefore glossed as \textsc{ana} for anaphoric. A typical tracking example is~(\ref{exe:semen}), where the referent semen `concrete', which is mentioned at minute 2:16, is mentioned again at minute 5:27, and marked with opa to indicate that it is the same concrete.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: When narrating a story with help of a stimulus\is{stimulus}, such as a picture book or a video, speakers may start the story by marking the first mention of a referent with opa, referring to the picture or video of the referent that they have just seen. (\ref{exe:kewerecg}) is an example of recognitional use.
Content 1: \gll tumun \textbf{opa} ma kewe-neko | \gls child ANA 3SG house-inside | \glt `That child is inside a house.'

Knowledge Point: It can also be used to establish shared knowledge. In~(\ref{exe:hadi}), the speaker uses opa to indicate to the listener that the referent is part of their shared knowledge.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Elevationals are typically used to describe referents and \is{location}locations inside the village, such as the beach (down) and other places in the village (up).\footnote{Karas is spoken on a limestone island that rises out of the sea. Both villages, Mas and Antalisa, are built on a strip of beach and the adjacent slopes.} (\ref{exe:keweosa}) shows the adnominal object form osanet \textsc{up.obj}, and~(\ref{exe:yawetko}) contains the locative form yawetko \textsc{down.loc}. Though yawe and osa (and their longer forms) are typically used adnominally, they may also be used as locative and lative forms, as in~(\ref{exe:desi}), where one would expect the locative form yawetko.
Content 1: \gll mu era kewe \textbf{osanet} nawanona | \gls 3PL ascend house UP.OBJ tidy | \glt `They went up to tidy the house up there.'
Content 2: \gll Desi opa me yal∼yal=te \textbf{yawe} | \gls Desi {\glopa} TOP paddle∼PROG={\glte} DOWN | \glt `Desi is paddling down there.'

Knowledge Point: Elevationals may be applied on both a smaller and bigger scale than the village. On a smaller scale, a speaker may use elevationals to refer to the immediate environment such as a house or a tree. In~(\ref{exe:tekya}), the speaker is looking for a knife in her house, and refers to her bedroom as being `down'. Yawe is not used to single out which bedroom, as the speaker has only one bedroom (and has already singled it out anyway by inflecting minggalot `bedroom' with a possessive marker).
Content 1: \gll ma tamatko ka bo minggalot-an \textbf{yawe} kome=te | \gls 3SG where 2SG go bedroom-1SG.POSS DOWN look=IMP | \glt `Where is it? You go look in my bedroom!'

Knowledge Point: On a larger scale, elevationals are used to talk about the wider landscape surrounding Mas, the village where all recordings for the Kalamang corpus were made. The direction of movement from the Karas Islands to Fakfak (the regency capital, NNE of the Karas Islands) is described as bara `move down', and from Fakfak to the Karas Islands as sara `move up'. Consequently, Fakfak is yawetko `down there'. This is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:muyawe}), which is about moneylenders in Fakfak.
Content 1: \gll mu \textbf{yawetko} in=bon sampaikan=et | \gls 3PL DOWN.LOC 1PL.EXCL=COM let.know=IRR | \glt `They down there let us know.'

Knowledge Point: The direction of movement from the Karas Islands to Malakuli (the district capital, east of the Karas Islands) is described as landwards, because it lies on the mainland of New Guinea. Nevertheless, Malakuli is osatko, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kiosa}), which refers to a house for schoolchildren from Mas which was being built in Malakuli at the time.
Content 1: \gll ki \textbf{osatko}=a kewe-paruot=kin | \gls 2PL UP.LOC=FOC house-make=VOL | \glt `Do you up there want to work on the house?'
